title: Where do Colorado Springs residents want to move?
summary:
click to enlarge Gregory HowellApartment List's latest migration report suggests Pueblo is a popular option for apartment hunters looking to move from Colorado Springs.
According to a new report, about a quarter of Colorado Springs residents hunting for apartments are looking to move elsewhere.
But the percentage of people outside the city looking for an apartment in Colorado Springs remained unchanged, at 54 percent.Taken together, those two factors suggest that the city is growing in population.About 15.5 percent of the people from outside Colorado Springs who were looking to move here lived in Denver, according to the latest report.
Apartment List's latest report on Colorado Springs rents showed that median rent grew 3.4 percent between December 2018 and December 2019, the fourth-highest such increase among metro areas in the U.S.Median rent for a two-bedroom apartment was $1,270 in December, according to Apartment List numbers for Colorado Springs.

title: New Colorado Springs Amazon Facility Will Bring 1,000+ Jobs To The City
summary:
Amazon has announced it will build a massive new order fulfillment center near the Colorado Springs airport, bringing more than a thousand new jobs to the economically distressed southeastern part of the city.
Amazon purchased the land for the new 800,000-square-foot building from the Colorado Springs Airport.
The airport’s director of aviation Greg Phillips said what’s planned will be far bigger than any other Amazon facility in the state.
Peak Innovation Park/Colorado Springs Airport A rendering of the planned business park near the Colorado Springs airport, which hopes to be anchored by a new Amazon fulfillment center.
The deal with Amazon was finalized last week and the city did not offer any tax incentives to secure the facility, Phillips said.

Whether it’s their numerous attacks on Coloradans’ healthcare or raiding millions of dollars from Peterson Air Force Base in Colorado Springs, it’s no wonder they’re both so profoundly unpopular here in Colorado.

title: Gannon Stauch case: Detectives suspected stepmother because of lies, erratic behavior, affidavit says
authors: A Western Kentucky University Journalism School Grad
Public Safety For The Denver Post. She Has Spent More Than Years In The Newspaper World. During That Time
She'S Covered Everything Rural Towns In The Southeast To Combat In The Middle East. The Denver Post Is Her Fifth Newspaper
summary:
Letecia Stauch originally told El Paso County sheriff’s deputies on Jan. 27 that her stepson had left to play with friends but never returned home.
Almost immediately her story did not hold up because she could not tell deputies the names of her stepson’s friends or of his friends’ parents, an El Paso County Sheriff’s Office detective wrote.
On Friday, the affidavit was unsealed by El Paso County District Court Judge Gregory R. Werner.
She is being held without bail in the El Paso County jail.
They listened as she offered various explanations to her husband, her sister and her friends, the affidavit said.

The Colorado Springs Police Department’s Violent Crimes Section responded to the scene and assumed responsibility for this investigation.

The first shooting happened around 10 a.m. on the west side of the Springs.

title: Couples in Colorado Springs take unconventional approach to Valentine’s Day
summary:
NewsCOLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. (KRDO) -- While many couples celebrate Valentine's Day with roses and candlelit dinners, some couples in Colorado Springs are aiming for a different approach at the popular holiday.
At the Whistling Pines Gun Club, couples enjoyed shooting a few rounds with their partner, followed by a complimentary dinner.
Gun Club owner Robert Holmes says that contrary to popular belief, this unconventional date night has proven to be most beneficial and enjoyed by women.
"A lot of women are nervous about going shooting, but when they're with other couples and their husband, that fear factor kind of goes away."
The Whistling Pines Gun Club hosts date night for couples once a month.

title: Copper Mountain sees snowiest February ever with 88″ of powder
authors: John Meyer Is A Member Of The Colorado Ski
The Colorado Running Hall Of Fame.
summary:
860 SharesWith 10 inches of fresh snow to report Monday morning, Copper Mountain broke its record for February snowfall.
With six days left in the month, Copper has received 88 inches of snow.
Winter Park has had its third-snowiest February, with 86 inches.
The record for Winter Park is 122.3 inches in 1993, when it snowed every day of the month except Valentine’s Day.
Winter Park probably won’t get enough snow this week to break its record, but it’s less than 2 inches behind its second-snowiest month (1989).

title: Marty's Sunday Morning Forecast
summary:
WeatherOverview: Another wave will likely bring some snow back to parts of the area today.
The pattern looks very active next week with cool air, periods of wind and occasional chances for at least some light snow at times for much of the week.
Today: Becoming mostly cloudy and breezy to windy at times with areas of snow developing near the higher terrain along and west of I-25 during the day.
It will be cold enough where the snow falls for even light accumulations of snow to cause some slick spot on the roads as we head towards this evening.
Some pockets of low cloud cover, patchy fog and possibly some light snow or flurries may remain in place into very early Monday morning along parts of the I-25 corridor suggesting there could be some areas where the roads may be a little slick for the Monday morning commute.

title: Marty's Saturday Morning Forecast
summary:
The air overhead would support 50s and 60s for most areas but much of the sun's energy will go into melting the fresh snow.
Where the snow was significant the temperatures will probably remain in the 40s, but for areas that didn't receive much snow 50s are more likely.
Snow will develop again over the ski resorts but we should remain dry locally.
Most areas look dry and a little warmer on Wednesday although some spotty snow showers may develop over the mountains late in the day into Wednesday night.
Scattered snow showers may develop over a few more areas on Thursday although it doesn’t currently appear that snowfall will be heavy right now.

title: Marty's Friday Evening Forecast
summary:
Saturday should be dry and warmer but another wave will likely bring some snow back to parts of the area starting Sunday.
By morning most areas will have cooled into the teens with a few areas near the mountains possibly holding in the 20s.
Extended: Another cold front will arrive on Sunday and likely cause snow to develop starting as early as Sunday morning for some areas.
It looks as though we'll have a cool, active pattern into next weekend with temperatures generally near or below average and occasional chances for some snow.
Right now snow chances look most likely on Thursday and then again perhaps as we head into next weekend, but we'll need to track subtle waves closely throughout the week.

title: Klobuchar to campaign in Aurora Thursday as 2020 candidates head to Colorado
summary:
DENVER – Six presidential candidates will campaign in Colorado in the three weeks ahead of the state’s Super Tuesday primary election, and with ballots already in voters’ hands.
Amy Klobuchar, the Democratic senator from Minnesota, is hosting an event on Thursday, Feb. 20, at 5 p.m. at the Stanley Marketplace in Aurora.
Bernie Sanders, the senator from Vermont, drew 11,000 people to his rally at the Colorado Convention Center in Denver on Sunday.
Pete Buttigieg, the former South Bend, Indiana mayor, will host a town hall in Aurora at 7 p.m. on Saturday, and Elizabeth Warren, the Democratic senator from Massachusetts, will host a campaign event Sunday at 3 p.m. at the Fillmore Auditorium in Denver.
President Trump is expected to win Colorado’s Republican primary but there have been no recent polls of the Democratic field in Colorado.

title: Pete Buttigieg To Hold Aurora Town Hall As Colorado Starts To Capitalize On Super Tuesday
authors: Colorado Public Radio Staff The Associated Press
summary:
Now that Michael Bennet is out of the race for the White House, Colorado is suddenly catching the eye of presidential candidates.
It doesn't hurt that the state is part of Super Tuesday on March 3.
South Bend, Indiana Mayor Pete Buttigieg, who won in Iowa and finished behind Bernie Sanders in New Hampshire, will host a town hall in Aurora on Feb. 22.
Unlike the last visit, which was a fundraiser, this event is free and open to the public.
It should also be noted that President Donald Trump's "Keep America Great" campaign will bring him to Colorado on Feb. 20 for a rally at the Broadmoor World Arena in Colorado Springs.

title: Marty's Sunday Morning Forecast
summary:
A strong and very cold storm should impact the area early next week bringing many of us another chance for snow.
The combination of dry air, wind and warmth will also lead to favorable fire weather conditions for parts of eastern Colorado.
The record high temperatures for Sunday are 66 and 75 for Colorado Springs and Pueblo respectively and either community could set a new record high temperature during the afternoon.
Scattered, mainly light snow showers might linger into Tuesday and with very cold air in place could keep roads slick at times.
We'll likely be windy at times through the end of the week as well.

title: How to vote in today’s Super Tuesday presidential primary in Colorado Springs
summary:
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. — Super Tuesday marks Colorado’s first presidential primary since 2000.
You can register to vote and receive a ballot at one of these centers until 7 p.m. Tuesday.
Unaffiliated voters who did not choose a party preference will receive a ballot packet containing one ballot for each party.
If an unaffiliated voter returns both ballots voted, neither will be counted.
Alternatively, you can get a new ballot and vote in person at a voter service and polling center.

title: Colorado Springs man killed in plane crash on DOC property
summary:
Top StoriesCANON CITY, Colo. - Authorities say one person died in the crash of a small plane on an instructional flight in southern Colorado.
An NTSB spokesman says the Piper PA-28 with three people on board crashed during take off from the Fremont County airport Sunday, landing on nearby land owned by the Colorado Department of Corrections.
The Fremont County coroner has identified the person killed as 39-year-old David Merritt of Colorado Springs.
A flight instructor, a student pilot and a passenger were on board but it's unclear which role Merritt held.
An NTSB investigator arrived at the crash site on Monday morning.

title: Marty's Saturday Morning Forecast
summary:
WeatherOverview: After a nice start to the weekend we're tracking another storm that will bring many areas wind, rain and snow.
Most areas will avoid real strong wind gusts today, but there will be breezy pockets, especially over and near the mountains.
Snow early Sunday morning will initially be wet and confined to the higher terrain, but as the air cools during the day snowfall elevations will fall with all but the far eastern plains eventually receiving some snow.
Temperatures Sunday morning will range from the 20s over the mountains to the 40s over the plains with most areas experiencing falling temperatures through the day.
For Colorado Springs, Pueblo and Canon City a general 1"- 4" of snow would appear most likely sometime Sunday morning into early Sunday afternoon.

On Tuesday, after receiving a special shipment of glycerin and hydrogen peroxide and following a World Health Organization recipe, Spirit Hound made a 48-gallon batch of 80-percent alcohol hand sanitizer.
Distillers across the country are making hand sanitizer during this unprecedented time, when stores are sold out and people are stockpiling, then reselling, the valuable product online for huge markups.
So far, Spirit Hound has donated its hand sanitizer to the Lyons Fire Protection District, local businesses and a Lyons home healthcare nurse, who passed some along to healthcare nonprofits.

title: Top 5 snowiest Octobers of all time in Southern Colorado
summary:

KOAA Colorado Springs October snowfall recordsAfter today's snowfall, Pueblo's total for the month at the airport is now up to 11.4", making it the third snowiest October since records have been kept.
KOAA Pueblo record snowOur most recent series of back-to-back storms this week also brought impressive 4-day snow totals to Southern Colorado.
Colorado Springs and Pueblo saw totals around 10", with the first storm favoring El Paso County, and the second one favoring Pueblo County.
KOAA 4-day snowfall totals in Southern ColoradoThe First Alert5 weather team is done tracking the snow for now, with the focus tonight on the dangerous cold.

title: When fall colors are expected to peak in Colorado in 2019
summary:
Each year, these slender white-barked trees show off a spectrum ranging from buttery yellow, champagne gold, amber orange, and blazing red – but timing is everything when it comes to seeing fall colors in Colorado.
SmokyMountains.com created an interactive map to determine peak fall colors across the nation for 2019.
Leaves in the northwest portion of Colorado are expected to peak around October 5, while fall foliage in the north-central and southwest Colorado will be near or at their peak by October 19.
As October comes to an end, fall colors across most of the state will have past their peak for 2019.
See when fall colors are expected to peak in other parts of the country here.

JACKSON, Miss.
(AP) — Strong storms pounded the Deep South on Sunday, killing at least six people in south Mississippi and damaging up to 300 homes and other buildings in northern Louisiana.
Storms continued to batter the South overnight, with much of the region under flash flood, tornado and thunderstorm warnings and watches.
Mississippi Emergency Management Agency director Greg Michel said one person killed was in Walthall County, two were killed in Lawrence County and three were killed in Jefferson Davis County.
All three counties are more than an hour's drive south of Jackson, near the Louisiana state line.

title: October 28: Weather through the years
summary:
COLORADO SPRINGS — RECORD SNOW ALERT!
Update as of October 29th shows both Colorado Springs and Pueblo set new daily snowfall records on the 28th.
Colorado Springs saw 6.8″ of snow, breaking the previous record of 0.9″ set it 1991.
Pueblo totals added up to 3.8″, breaking the 2.9″ record set in 1917.
In 2009, temperatures were warmer but not by much with a max temp of 34° and a minimum of 26°, but no snow was reported on October 28, 2009.

title: Colorado Went From Summer To Winter And No, That’s Not Really Normal
summary:
Becky Bolinger with the Colorado Climate Center said the snowstorm combined with extremely cold temperatures has been unusual for this month.
“The snowstorms we typically have in October aren't really associated with air that is this cold,” she said.
“This is more consistent with the cold air we might expect to see in December or January.
“It pretty much feels like we went from a summer month to a winter month,” she said.
The wavy weather pattern right now is causing cold temperatures and snow in Colorado but has brought heat to other places like Alaska, where the weather is still relatively warm.

title: 20+ inches of snow to fall in parts of Colorado
summary:
October snow is piling up fast in Colorado, with up to 23 more inches of snow on the way.
Accumulations will range from 1 to 23 inches across portions of south-central and southeast Colorado.
The fast-moving storm could leave up 10 to 20 inches of snow in parts of southern Colorado, including Walsenburg and Trinidad, according to Fox21 News.
Woodland park could see up to 16 inches and Castle Rock up to 10 inches, with as much as 23 inches of snow possible on the summit of Pikes Peak.
Severe winter weather conditions will likely make travel very difficult Wednesday evening into Thursday afternoon.

title: Colorado records its fourth-coldest October on record
authors: Science For The Denver Post. He Has His Certification In Broadcast Meteorology Mississippi State University
He Also Holds A Broadcasters' Seal Of Approval The National Weather Association. He Works Full-Time As A Broadcast Meteorologist At Weathernation
A National Weather Network Headquartered In Centennial.
summary:
Colorado recorded its coldest statewide October in a decade and its fourth-coldest overall, based on official data from the National Centers for Environmental Information (NCEI).
Colorado recorded an average statewide temperature of 41.2 degrees in October, 5.3 degrees below the monthly average.
Colorado’s average minimum temperature in October was 25.9 degrees, 6.1 degrees below the monthly average low of 32.0 degrees.
Overall, Colorado is also experiencing its coldest start to a year since 2008, through October.
Through Wednesday, Denver’s average November temperature was 7.3 degrees below average, and Grand Junction, Pueblo and Colorado Springs were all running well below month-to-date average levels as well.

title: Where to get flu shots in Colorado Springs
summary:
click to enlarge ShutterstockThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends you get a flu shot before the end of October, but getting vaccinated remains worthwhile late into the year.
And the answer to that is yes," says Cynthia Wacker, manager of Mission Ministry & Outreach for Penrose-St. Francis Health Services.
"It really does last — keeps that immunity for up to a year — but you do need to get a flu shot every year.
"Flu shots are especially important for members of high-risk groups, including children younger than 5, adults older than 65, pregnant women, nursing home residents and those with certain medical conditions.
For example, a 20-something with a poor diet might experience worse symptoms than a healthy, active senior.Regardless of your own risk factors, don't just get a flu shot for yourself, Wacker says.

title: How much and when? Our current forecast for snow Thursday
summary:
Here's our current thinking of when the snow will arrive and how much you'll see.
This is a north wind driven snow event, meaning that the Pikes Peak Region, specifically the northern side of the Monument Hill and Teller County, will probably see the heaviest snow.
Snow will likely start falling mid morning in northern El Paso and Teller Counties, spreading south through the rest of the day..
It's likely the morning commute will be unaffected here in southern Colorado, but snow will begin falling in Denver sometime around or after 6 am.
As mentioned before, there will be a strong northerly winds pushing snow primarily to the north side of Monument Hill and Teller County.

title: Colorado rafting season expected to go long this year, extending into early fall
authors: John Meyer Is A Member Of The Colorado Ski
The Colorado Running Hall Of Fame.
summary:
1.8K SharesColorado rafting companies are planning for extended seasons reaching into October, thanks to abundant snowfall last winter and spring that promises to keep flows strong through the summer.
June brought high water levels, but with the arrival of warm temperatures and the passage of peak runoff, river flows currently are described as moderate — and there’s plenty more to come.
“All geographic areas have different levels of rafting, but we’re anticipating many runs will be open later this season than they have in several years,” said David Costlow, executive director of the Colorado River Outfitters Association in a news release.
In the Durango area, which saw meager flows a year ago due to drought, the Animas should support rafting through September.
Sections of the Arkansas likely will be raftable through September and, closer to Denver, Clear Creek should have rafting well into August.

title: Typhoon to result in cold weather, snow in Colorado
summary:
According to the National Weather Service, a recurving typhoon in the West Pacific is bringing frigid temperatures and two rounds of snow to parts of Colorado into early next week.
For the #weathernerds out there, look at how the recurving typhoon leads to the deepening of an anomalously strong trough that is responsible for our snow and bitter cold early next week.
Up to 12 inches of snow could fall across Colorado Springs, Castle Rock, Pueblo, Estes Park, Boulder, Vail, Fairplay, Walsenburg, Westcliffe, and Winter Park.
Up to 8 inches of snow could fall over the Denver area, Cañon City, Aspen, Fort Collins, and Salida.
The second round of snow expected Tuesday into Wednesday could drop 5 additional inches of snow across parts of the state.

The Space Symposium — which attracts thousands of space industry professionals to Colorado Springs each year, boosting the city’s economy — is back on the calendar for the fall.

ECONOMIC IMPACTThe Space Symposium is “by far the largest convention held in Colorado Springs each year,” according to Mayor John Suthers.
Because a lot of business is done — millions, if not billions of dollars — as a result of relationships formed at the Space Symposium.

title: Colorado's snowpack starting to shrink after a lackluster start to November
summary:
Some mountain areas received as much as 4 to 5 feet of snow in October, which initially led to massive gains in our state's snowpack levels.
Looking at our state's snowpack, numbers this month have been falling fast as the lack of snow the past few days takes a toll.
The state's snowpack is now under 100% for the first time this season.
When it comes to November averages, we typically see between 4 and 5 inches of snow for the Springs and Pueblo.
Trinidad averages 7.5 inches in November, while Leadville in Lake County averages almost 24 inches of snow.

title: Here’s How Much It Snowed In That Pre-Thanksgiving Storm
summary:
"This storm this week has been the biggest storm thus far this year," state climatologist Ross Schumacher said.
It was the biggest November snowstorm for Denver since 1994, and the snowiest day in the city in more than three years, according to WeatherNation TV.
Tuesday also marked the third snowiest day ever in Boulder, and the second snowiest November day in Fort Collins, according to the Colorado Climate Center.
"It doesn't look like we have any more big storms on the immediate horizon for the Front Range," Schumacher said.
But on the other side of the state, forecasts say another big storm is coming for Western Colorado.

title: District Attorney formally files first-degree murder charges against Randy Bishop
summary:
COLORADO SPRINGS — On Tuesday afternoon, the 4th Judicial District Attorney’s Office filed formal charges against Randy Bishop for first-degree murder (after deliberation) of Thomas Anthony Faircloth.
The 35-year-old is facing charges in multiple cases, including first-degree murder (after deliberation), attempted first-degree murder of a peace officer, second-degree assault of a peace officer, and many other charges.
On March 12, 2020, Bishop was arrested on the charge of second-degree murder in the death of Thomas Anthony Faircloth.
On Tuesday, The District Attorney’s office filed the formal charge of murder in the first-degree (after deliberation).
Randy Bishop, 35, was arrested January 26, after months on the run.

title: Colorado Springs Airport easier than Denver for Thanksgiving travelers
summary:
NewsThe Wednesday before Thanksgiving is said to be the busiest day of the year when it comes to travel, and it was made even busier with the large storm that slammed Colorado Springs Monday night into Tuesday morning.
Much of the travel that was supposed to take place on Tuesday ended up being pushed forward to Monday night or pushed back to Wednesday.
This was despite the fact that Tuesday actually proved to be a fairly easy day for the Colorado Springs Airport, with the majority of the delays or cancelations primarily coming from Denver.
With plenty of people rescheduling their flights for Wednesday, it's important to remember to get to the airport early and pack your patience, especially during the holiday season.
Don't forget, the airport is offering 50% off long terms parking through the new year.

title: Colorado snowpack back above average after huge week of snow
authors: Science For The Denver Post. He Has His Certification In Broadcast Meteorology Mississippi State University
He Also Holds A Broadcasters' Seal Of Approval The National Weather Association. He Works Full-Time As A Broadcast Meteorologist At Weathernation
A National Weather Network Headquartered In Centennial.
summary:
After a huge week of snowfall across most of the state, Colorado’s statewide snowpack levels are back above average.
As of Monday’s Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) update, Colorado statewide snowpack levels were running at 117% of the season-to-date levels, meaning that statewide snow levels are slightly above average.
The main driver behind the recent uptick in snow levels?
That helped boost snowpack percentages in southern Colorado well above average, while also boosting overall statewide levels.
According to the NRCS, statewide snowpack levels had dropped marginally below average from the second week of November through Nov. 27, when a series of big storms began moving through Colorado.

title: Denver City Council unanimously approves minimum wage hike starting Jan. 1
authors: Conrad Swanson Covers Denver Politics On The Denver Post S Political Team. An Iowa Native
He Joined The Paper In November After Stints At The Colorado Springs Gazette
Iowa . He Graduated The University Of Iowa With A Bachelor S Degree In Journalism
A Focus In Economics. He Is A Member Of The Investigative Reporters
summary:
The Denver City Council unanimously increased the citywide minimum wage Monday night to thundering applause throughout its chambers.
Public comment was overwhelmingly, if not entirely, in favor of the law, which places Denver as the first Colorado city to raise the local minimum wage.
The federal minimum wage hasn’t changed since 2009.
The statewide minimum wage will rise to $12 an hour next year, but a new state law enables local governments to set higher minimum wages starting Jan. 1.
Even with the new law, tipped workers can be paid $3.02 per hour less than the minimum wage.

Voting unanimously on Nov. 12, Colorado Springs City Council gave the nod to technical approvals that clear the way for construction of an 8,000-seat stadium on 4.9 acres southwest of Cimarron and Sahwatch streets.
The approval comes nearly six years after the state Economic Development Commission in December 2013 granted $120.5 million in state sales tax rebates to fund the City for Champions initiative, of which the stadium is a part.
The stadium can accommodate 15,000 attendees for concerts, and will be the home field for the Colorado Springs Switchbacks soccer club.

Durango used to have a higher snow budget, around $900,000 in 2009 and 2010, but tax cuts made that number an impossible one to stay at.

title: Study says you need $118k to ‘be happy’ in Colorado Springs
summary:
Using that study's findings, financial literacy website GOBanking Rates predicted the annual salary a single person would need to be happy in 50 of America's biggest cities.
According to their predictions, someone living in Colorado Springs would need an annual income of $118,545 to "be happy."
The university's research aimed to "pinpoint the amount where money no longer changes your level of emotional well-being and 'life evaluation.'"
Researchers further broke down requisite income for "life evaluation," which they say needs $107,255 in Colorado Springs, and "emotional well-being," which they say needs between $67,740 and $84,675.
In comparison, the researchers say someone living in Denver would need $151,410 to be happy, $136,990 for life evaluation, and $86,520 - $108,150 for emotional well-being.

Colorado is among communities where rent costs increased in 2019.

title: Colorado Springs exceeds snow removal budget for 2019
summary:
MoneyWith the official start of winter still a few days away, the frequency of fall snowstorms is straining the snow removal budget in Colorado Springs.
The city bases its budget on a "typical" snowfall year, even though the amount of snowfall can change significantly from year to year.
However, officials said they can balance the snow removal budget through cost savings in the overall city budget and other areas of the public works department.
Some citizens on social media said the city should include a greater likelihood of above-normal snow events, and rely less on typical years, when formulating its annual snow removal budget.
Officials said the greatest percentage of the snow removal budget is spent on materials such as sand and salt.

The USAF STEM Program provided $19,000 in educational grants to these teams.
"Once again, over the course of another successful season, our competitors have shown they have the 'right stuff' to lead the future of US space," said Stephen K. Gourley, StellarXplorers program director.
StellarXplorers is an AFA program aimed at inspiring students to pursue education and careers in STEM fields using space system engineering.

title: Colorado Springs Festival of Lights happening on December 7
summary:
COLORADO SPRINGS — Make sure you stop by Downtown Colorado Springs on December 7 for the 35th annual Festival of Lights Parade.
The Parade will be on Tejon St. and will start at St. Vrain St. and proceed south to Vermijo Avenue.
The Colorado Springs Pioneers Museum will host its annual Festival of Lights Family Fun Day Saturday from 10 am to 2 pm.
Festival of Lights Family Fun Day is free and open to the public.
The Festival of Lights Parade is a nonprofit organization, established to ensure that the citizens of the Pikes Peak Region are able to enjoy this tradition each December.

title: Gift returns in Colorado Springs bring crowds to stores on day after Christmas
summary:
LifestyleCOLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. (KRDO) -- The day after Christmas is the busiest day for bringing back presents that were the wrong size, wrong color or otherwise unwanted.
There were enough customers returning merchandise to fill store aisles in Colorado Springs Thursday, although some shoppers told KRDO that they didn't need to return gifts.
Stores have a variety of return policies; some have limited times for providing cash refunds while others give gift cards.
A growing trend for the day after Christmas is to return packages at delivery stores such as the UPS Store in Stetson Hills on the city's northeast side.
More than 75% of the packages we'll handle are Amazon packages.

summary:

title: How Cold Has It Been? Colorado’s Had The Lowest Temperature In The Lower 48 States For Two Days In A Row
summary:
For two days in a row, Antero Reservoir in Park County has had the lowest temperature recorded in the United States at — brrr — 48 degrees below zero.
On Monday, Crested Butte recorded a temperature of -31 degrees Fahrenheit.
Jim Kalina, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service, said Antero Reservoir — which is about 75 miles west of Colorado Springs — typically gets that cold every year at least a couple times.
The coldest temperature recorded there ever was was -54 degrees.
When they do get the snow cover up there, that sets them up for these really cold temperatures."

title: Snow headed to Colorado Springs!
summary:
Local ForecastThe warm and dry weather will finally be coming to an end with winter weather returning to the I-25 corridor Friday afternoon.
A low-pressure center located in New Mexico Friday afternoon will track through far SE Colorado, transporting enough instability and moisture to whip up a few snow showers that will reach into Colorado Springs.
I feel comfortable with a 1"-3" forecast through Saturday morning in the Springs.
Snow accumulation for El Paso County will be closer to 3" the further south you are.
Hopefully with the updated model runs we'll have a better feel for the rain/snow event by tomorrow afternoon and can provide a more detailed forecast.

Police officers were called to the area of Las Vegas St. and Nevada Ave. just before 6 a.m.
Police had told KRDO that the driver was nowhere to be found following the crash.
Investigators on the scene then told us the driver had been charged and then released.
Police say could have played a major factor in not seeing the pedestrian cross the street.

title: Colorado Springs man reportedly robs bank, throws money into the air and yells, “Merry Christmas”
authors: Sam Tabachnik Is A Breaking News Reporter For The Denver Post
summary:
A 65-year-old man was arrested Monday after robbing a bank in downtown Colorado Springs, before reportedly walking outside, throwing the money into air and yelling, “Merry Christmas!”Around 12:27 p.m. Monday, David Oliver allegedly threatened employees of the Academy Bank at 1 South Tejon Street with a weapon, leaving the bank with an undisclosed amount of cash, according to the Colorado Springs police blotter.
A witness told KKTV that Oliver then walked outside, threw the bills into the air and shouted his festive message.
Jim Jeffocat, a Colorado Springs police spokesman, would not confirm that money was thrown into air or that Oliver yelled “Merry Christmas.”Oliver then sat on the patio of the Starbucks coffee shop next door, where police arrested him without conflict, police said.
The witness told KKTV that people walking down the street stopped to pick up the flying bills to return to the bank tellers.
Officers found no indication that Oliver was armed with a weapon, Jeffcoat said.

title: Slayer and co. thrash Colorado Springs
summary:
On Wednesday, Nov. 20, 2019, the mind-boggling became real: Slayer headlined the Broadmoor World Arena.
But it’s the final leg of Slayer’s farewell tour, dubbed “The Final Campaign,” and the lineup was stacked with headline-grade talent.
Between the flashing lights, the scrap-metal cross and the psychedelic-meets-Matrix video reels on the projector, they set a great vibe.
If we had to complain, we’d wish the setlist had a few of the band’s slower tracks to break up the full-speed-ahead thrash attack.
But this is Slayer doing everything they needed to do: fast, heavy, and always at maximum volume.

title: Colorado Springs storm cleanup shifts from snow and ice to gravel
summary:
NewsCOLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. -- The anti-skid material applied by street crews during winter weather in Colorado Springs provides traction for drivers in ice and snow, but its usefulness ends once the frozen precipitation melts.
Many drivers may not realize that most of the material -- a mixture of gravel and salt -- used to be picked up within days after a storm event.
With the size of our city, the limited resources and the miles of streets we have, it's hard to remove material any more often."
Picking up the material also removes dust that can accumulate on streets and along curbs after a storm.
El Paso County crews don't have a similar requirement and the Colorado Department of Transportation doesn't use anti-skid materials in Colorado Springs.

title: Where do Colorado Springs residents want to move?
summary:
click to enlarge Gregory HowellApartment List's latest migration report suggests Pueblo is a popular option for apartment hunters looking to move from Colorado Springs.
According to a new report, about a quarter of Colorado Springs residents hunting for apartments are looking to move elsewhere.
But the percentage of people outside the city looking for an apartment in Colorado Springs remained unchanged, at 54 percent.Taken together, those two factors suggest that the city is growing in population.About 15.5 percent of the people from outside Colorado Springs who were looking to move here lived in Denver, according to the latest report.
Apartment List's latest report on Colorado Springs rents showed that median rent grew 3.4 percent between December 2018 and December 2019, the fourth-highest such increase among metro areas in the U.S.Median rent for a two-bedroom apartment was $1,270 in December, according to Apartment List numbers for Colorado Springs.
A typical two-bedroom apartment costs about $80 more a month in Denver than in Colorado Springs.

title: How does Colorado Springs avoid becoming Denver?
summary:
As I was cursing my windshield in the gridlock, one question kept repeating itself in my head: How does Colorado Springs avoid becoming Denver?
By 2050, Colorado Springs will pull ahead of Denver as the state’s biggest city, according to Cindy DeGroen, the state’s projections demographer.
The good news is that Colorado Springs and Denver are very different cities in significant ways that will probably benefit the livability of Colorado Springs in the years to come.
But the mayor, for one, thinks that ability to sprawl is actually a good thing for Colorado Springs and will mean that Colorado Springs won’t have the traffic problems Denver has.
I’d like to see a strategic, citywide plan put forth for 2050, when Colorado Springs will be the biggest city in Colorado.

title: Hiring process begins in Colorado Springs for the 2020 census
summary:
Colorado SpringsCOLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. (KRDO) -- The 2020 census is right around the corner, which means the U.S. Census Bureau is hard at work trying to fill part-time employee positions.
This time around, a census bureau is located right here in Colorado Springs and they are personally in charge of handling 38 Counties here in Colorado.
Vaughn Jones with the Colorado Springs Census Bureau Office said, “We want people that are people people, and they are not afraid to approach people and talk to them.”With the hiring process starting last week, potential new hires have a short amount of time to get their applications in as the hiring process will only run through February.
The U.S. Census Bureau decided to raise the rate for new hires from a minimum of $14 per hour to $16.
And the 2020 census is something that the Census Bureau and city officials are taking very seriously.

title: Colorado Springs Mayor ‘confident’ homeless camping laws could stand up in court
summary:
NewsCOLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. (KRDO) -- After a recent ruling in Denver, Colorado Springs Mayor John Suthers says he's confident the city's law against homeless camping would stand in court.
On Friday, a judge ruled Denver's urban camping unconstitutional, citing available shelter beds were not always accessible to everyone who might need them.
In 2019, shelters in Colorado Springs have more than 650 beds available to those who might need it.
"Even in the bomb cyclone last March, we had empty shelter beds," Suthers said.
The Colorado Springs Police Homeless Outreach Team is in charge of handing out citations for those who don't follow the law.

title: Colorado Springs authorities rope off pavilion at second downtown-area park due to homeless
summary:
LifestyleCOLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. -- For the second time in four months -- because of apparent issues related to the homeless -- authorities have limited access to a picnic shelter at a park near downtown Colorado Springs.
A witness told KRDO Wednesday that police and city workers installed cable barriers and signs around the pavilion at Antlers Park about two weeks ago.
On Wednesday, city workers cleaned up the area and police ordered a handful of homeless people to leave.
The officer, a member of the police's Homeless Outreach Team, said he didn't know enough about the Antlers Park pavilion to address it.
"In the summer, we'd come here every day because there was so much trash," the crew member said.

title: Colorado weather: Baby it's cold outside, as in 48 degrees below zero
summary:
The temperature reached 48 degrees below zero overnight Sunday at the popular fishing spot 76 miles west of Colorado Springs, according to the National Weather Service.
That's likely to be the coldest recorded low temperature in the lower 48 states for the day.
It was 44 degrees below zero on Dec. 17, 32 degrees below zero on Dec. 19, 13 degrees below zero on Dec. 23 and 9 degrees below zero on Dec. 24.
In addition to Antero's marks, Waverly, which is near Alamosa, had lows of 20 degrees below zero on Dec. 20 and 15 degrees below zero on Dec. 15.
2020 ROADWORK: Strap in north I-25 driversDespite hitting 48 degrees below zero, Antero's cold night is still 13 degrees from tying the state's coldest recorded temperature.

title: More Snow For Southern Colorado
summary:
NewsA major winter storm is headed for the Southern Foothills and adjacent plains Sunday into Monday where some areas south and southwest of Pueblo could receive a foot of snow or more.
WINTER STORM WARNINGS are in effect for Teller and western El Paso Counties into early Monday morning..Colorado Springs will be under a WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY Sunday morning.
Snowfall amounts will probably range from 1 and 4 inches by Monday afternoon, but a few neighborhoods could receive more, especially south/southwest of downtown.
It'll be cold so any snow that falls Sunday night into Monday morning will result in slick travel.

title: Colorado snowpack improves but severe drought still persists
summary:
KOAA Current snowpack for ColoradoThe snowpack is vital to our state in that it provides us with drinking water and water to grow crops.
KOAA Current Colorado drought conditionsCurrent drought levels in Colorado Springs and Pueblo are considered to be "Abnormally Dry".
In southwest Colorado, the worst of the drought can be seen here in the form of a "Severe Drought".
Per the latest report from the U.S. Drought Monitor, "Severe Drought" conditions also remain over parts of Baca County.
These numbers could get worse before they get better, but as our state's snowpack builds, it's a positive sign that the drought will improve in the spring of 2020.

title: City discusses parking plan for new stadium
summary:
A parking study submitted with the development plan estimates that a crowd that size would need around 1,200 parking spaces, assuming an average of 2.9 passengers per car.
They identified 3,300 parking spaces within a 10 minute walk of the stadium.
The parking study cautions that soccer fans could find themselves competing with patrons of the Pikes Peak Center for the same parking spaces.
Another concern with the dispersed parking concept is a lack of Americans with Disability Act (ADA) accessible parking spaces.
Additional recommendations include extending the hours of parking meter enforcement for shops and restaurants located near the stadium and provide attendees with a map or smartphone application to help locate appropriate parking spaces.

title: Colorado Springs Utilities light exchange program underway
summary:
COLORADO SPRINGS — The holiday season can be a stressful time, especially financially for many families.
Which is part of the reason why Colorado Springs Utilities (CSU) is offering up some help for people to exchange their old lights for LED ones.
"They are safer, they are sturdier and they will last longer so they will save you money on your utilities bill," said Danielle Oller, Public Affairs Specialist with Colorado Springs Utilities.
Anyone can take their old Christmas lights to the CSU Conservation and Environmental Center (2855 Mesa Rd, Colorado Springs, CO 80904).

title: ‘Unusual’ ice layers persist on streets, parking lots in Colorado Springs
summary:
NewsColorado Springs residents are used to seeing snow and ice quickly melt from streets, roads and parking lots when sunshine and warmer temperatures arrive after a winter storm.
Ice also accumulates in areas of the city where underground springs produce a steady flow of water.

title: Colorado Springs man pleads guilty to holding strangers at gunpoint
summary:
NewsASPEN, Colo. - A Colorado man accused of holding three strangers at gunpoint on Independence Pass near Aspen has pleaded guilty to menacing and attempted kidnapping.
The Aspen Times reports 33-year-old Brolin McConnell, of Colorado Springs, struck a deal with prosecutors and pleaded guilty Tuesday.
He is scheduled to be sentenced Feb. 3.
Prosecutors say he held the men at gunpoint in July 2016, forced them to remove their shirts and repeatedly threatened to kill them as he fired guns at birds he said were drones.
The men were able to escape.

title: Shoppers brave the snow storm in Colorado Springs
summary:
NewsOn Sunday afternoon, shoppers trying to shop local braved frigid temperatures and snow showers in Downtown Colorado Springs.
Wylene Carol said, "The snow is beautiful and it's not all that cold."
By 4 o'clock, the snow had started to stick, making shoppers scatter and prompting natives to warn visitors.
Don't even attempt to do it if you're not used to it," said Jamie Migel.
By nightfall, the roads through downtown were snow-packed and all shoppers were gone.

title: Entire Colorado Springs apartment complex ordered to vacate due to asbestos
summary:
Top StoriesAn asbestos outbreak has led to an entire apartment complex of 192 units in Colorado Springs needing to be evacuated.
Residents say that the complex has offered money for the essentials along with a paid hotel room until they find a place to stay.
With this coming right before the holidays, the timing couldn’t be any worse, some residents say.
Residents say they are being told they will be refunded for December's rent, which was paid just a few days ago.
We tried speaking with the apartment complex, but they would not issue us a statement on the matter.

summary:

After a theft on Christmas Eve, he's left without some of the Christmas gifts he bought his family.

title: Marty's Saturday Morning Forecast
summary:

title: Weather slows some trash pickup along I-25 in Colorado Springs
summary:
NewsCOLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. -- If it seems that there's more trash lately along Interstate 25 in the Colorado Springs area, you may be right.
According to the Colorado Department of Transportation, the frequency of snowstorms this fall is delaying some trash removal.
Peulen said CDOT has a contract with a private agency to pick up bags of trash along the freeway.
The private agency employs former prison inmates who do the work as part of their parole -- replacing Keep Colorado Springs Beautiful, which employed volunteers who working off community service time.
CDOT has an Adopt a Highway program, in which organizations and businesses volunteer to pick up trash along certain highways.
